comments.html:
Hi,

what I've wondered since VXLAN first showed up along with other "half-proprietary" options, why is this used over other vlan "tunnel" solutions (I think there's S-VLAN? and, of course, QinQ?).

I'll try to re-read the post a few more times, but I've really never understood why we needed one more "trunk" standard.
(I'm aware everything has flaws, i.e. i think there was bad support for qinq in Linux, not letting you set the ethertype because someone didn't *get* it.)

Still, is there any big advantage in the VXLAN way of things over normal "stacked VLAN" setups?
comments.name: darkfader

comments.html: @darkfaber: VXLAN was introduced because it supports tunneling over IP Fabrics and because it has good support for multipath (entropy in UDP source port).  S-VLAN and QinQ cannot tunnel over an IP Fabric; they only support Ethernet Fabrics.  IP Fabrics are more scalable than Ethernet Fabrics.
comments.name: Bruno Rijsman

comments.html: I think vmware has introduced vxlan in order to release the Admins from the Network guys. That's nice in the way Network Dinos can focus on things that matter (aka the upper layer). And not provision VLANs on dumb switches all day long, for a virtual admin team that doesn't understand their own technology anyway.
